page.title: 04Landscape - Vegetation
page.content: Nowhere on the May Isle is there ay great depth of soil and the vegetation has been strongly influenced by salt spray and seabirds (especially gulls). Until the 1960's much of the surface was covered by a thin turf of fescue and bent grasses, with clumps of sea pinks and sea campion which flowered profusely in May and June. However, since then the rapid increase in the number of gulls and the spreading of colonies inland radically altered the vegetation in a very short time. As the gulls advanced so the vegetation declined partly from the effects of gull droppings and tramplingand partly from the wholesale tearing up of plants by gulls for nest building and courtship display. However there are still areas, in the south, of ground carpeted with sea campion. There are trees on the island and few bushes.
